Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Situation2: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading my sister’s text: “Can we talk tonight? I really need you.” She’d been struggling lately, and I’d promised myself I’d be more patient, more understanding—she deserved that from me. But then, another message popped up from Alex: “Hey, let’s do something tonight! I miss you.” We’d both finally found a week with free evenings, and I knew he was hoping for more time together, just us. I wanted to be the supportive sister, to listen without judgment, to show her I respected her feelings. But I also wanted to be the girlfriend who made Alex feel special, who didn’t always put him second. My heart twisted as I weighed their needs against my own. I could almost hear my sister’s voice, fragile and hopeful, and Alex’s, warm and expectant. I wished I could split myself in two, but I couldn’t. My thumb hovered over the screen, torn between two worlds, feeling the pressure of both roles pressing in on me.
